cards.front: What is a change of basis?
cards.back:
Converting how a vector is described between two different coordinate systems with different basis vectors.

The same geometric vector can have different numerical coordinates depending on your choice of basis.

cards.front: How do you translate coordinates from a new basis to the standard basis?
cards.back:
Create a change-of-basis matrix \( P \) whose columns are the new basis vectors expressed in standard coordinates.

\( \text{(standard coordinates)} = P \times \text{(new basis coordinates)} \)

P converts: new basis → standard basis.

cards.front: How do you translate coordinates from the standard basis to a new basis?
cards.back:
Use \( P^{-1} \), where \( P \) is the change-of-basis matrix (columns = new basis vectors in standard coordinates).

\( \text{(new basis coordinates)} = P^{-1} \times \text{(standard coordinates)} \)

P^{-1} converts: standard basis → new basis.

cards.front: What does \( P^{-1}AP \) represent, where \( P \) is a change-of-basis matrix?
cards.back:
The same transformation \( A \) expressed in the basis defined by \( P \)'s columns.

Reading right-to-left when applied to a vector:

  1. \( P \): convert from new basis to standard
  2. \( A \): apply transformation in standard basis
  3. \( P^{-1} \): convert result back to new basis

This is called a similarity transformation.

cards.front: Why is change of basis useful?
cards.back:
Some bases make certain transformations simpler.

For example, choosing eigenvectors as a basis can turn a complex matrix into a simple diagonal matrix.

Two matrices \( A \) and \( B \) are similar if there exists an invertible matrix \( P \) such that:

\( B = P^{-1}AP \)

Here \( P \) is a change-of-basis matrix (columns = new basis vectors in standard coordinates). Similar matrices represent the same linear transformation in different bases.

cards.front: What properties do similar matrices share?
cards.back:
Similar matrices have the same:

  • Determinant
  • Trace
  • Eigenvalues
  • Rank
  • Characteristic polynomial

These are called similarity invariants.

cards.front: If \( A \) and \( B \) are similar matrices (\( B = P^{-1}AP \)), what can you say about \( A^n \) and \( B^n \)?
cards.back:
They are also similar: \( B^n = P^{-1}A^nP \).

This is useful for computing powers: if \( P \) diagonalizes \( A \), then \( B \) is diagonal and \( B^n \) is trivial to compute.

cards.front: When is a matrix similar to a diagonal matrix?
cards.back:
When the matrix is diagonalizable, i.e., when it has \( n \) linearly independent eigenvectors for an \( n \times n \) matrix.

The diagonal matrix has the eigenvalues on its diagonal.
